723679f-b.text:
(1)

University Place, north from E. 9th Street (intersection shown in the foreground) as photographed from No. 1 University Place, an apartment structure at the N.E. corner of Waverly Place. The four tallest structures in the background are, the Empire state, the Metropolitan, the New York Life and the Chrysler Buildings.

July 17, 1935.

P.L. Sperr

(2)

#41 University Place, at the North East corner of East 9th Street, showing the Correll Press. The old house number
#31 may be noted on the window pane.

About 1894.

Photograph by,
J.J.Correll.
P.L.Sperr Collection.

(1)

University Place, north from E. 9th Street (intersection shown in the foreground) as photographed from No. 1 University Place, an apartment structure at the N.E. corner of Waverly Place. 723678f-a.text:
University Place at the northeast corner of 9th Street, showing spires of the University Place Presbyterian Church on the south
east corner of 10th Street.
P.L. Sperr  about 1895

723681f-a.text:
(1)

19-13 University Place, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of 9th Street. Building shown is the former Hotel Martin (opened 1883) and known as the Lafayette since 1902.

About 1895.

(2)

The same at a later date and showing the former Hotel Martin
as the present Lafayette (March 1902).

February 12, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

723680f-a.text:
University Place, west side, north from 9th Street. The 6-story office building, from 9th to 10th Streets, marked for sale, was built prior to 1891, and will be demolished prior to 1930.
In the background may be seen the Metropolitan Life clock tower at Madison Avenue and 24th Street.
May, 1913.

Brown Brothers.

Neg #575

723682f-a.text:
University Place, west side, north from and including 9th Street. A comparison with Brown Brothers' 1913 view shows little change in the buildings, except at the N.W. corner of 12th Street. The building on the S.W. corner of 9th Street, shown in part, was erected around 1900 on the site of six old houses. The building from 9th to 10th Streets, marked "For Sale" in the 1913 view, is at least ten years older; and the one on the N.W. corner of 10th Street looks like about 1880. The former will be replaced by a 12-story apartment house, and the latter, together with the 4-story house adjoining it, by an 11-story apartment house, in both cases prior to 1930.

June, 1925

Neg #576

723685f-a.text:
(1)

University Place, east side, from the N.E. corner of 10th Street to the S.E. corner of 9th Street, inclusive, showing demolition of the old University Place Presbyterian Church (1845) on the S.E. corner of 10th Street.
The Hotel Lafayette, owned by Raymond Orteig, is shown on the S.E. corner of 9th Street. Mr. Orteig was offering a cash prize for the first non-stop flight from New York to Paris; it was won by Charles A. Lindbergh, Jr., who took off from Roosevelt Field only three days after the date of this picture.
May 17, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, showing Devonshire House, the new 12-story apartment building just completed on the site of the church and parish house. This view also shows University Place on the east side all the way to 8th Street.
February 12, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

711005f-a.text:
East 9th Street, north side, east from (No. 51) a point midway between University Place and Broadway, and across the latter. The bridge affair shown connects two buildings of John Wanamakers Department Store.

May 21, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

Neg #565
